Award.AwardTitle: US-Egypt Planning Visits: Characterization and Assessment of Industrial Wastewaters in Egypt
Award.AbstractNarration:
1104027
This project supports a cooperative research planning project by Dr. Robert Peters, University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) and Dr. Mohamed Darwish, Alexandria University, Egypt, with participation from Misr University of Science and Technology (MUST) in Cairo, Egypt. They plan to study issues and to explore possible research areas aimed at improving water quality in Egypt.

Intellectual merits: The PI lists a number of tasks including prioritizing the pollutant loads/impacts of wastewaters from different industrial sectors; identifying specific industrial sectors that contribute significant quantities of pollutants to wastewaters and surface waters; identifying techniques to collect and analyze the chemical constituents and wastewater characteristics of wastewaters being emitted by various industrial firms; targeting pollution prevention assessments/audits of selected industrial firms, and presenting the results in workshops in both the U.S. and Egypt. There is the potential to conduct needed research with an appropriate emphasis on sustainability issues including considering the production of methane from organic wastes. Because of the large and growing population in the major cities, water quantity and water reuse may be of importance as well. Preliminary analysis of water samples collected at various several strategic points in Egypt will be performed and results will be used to identify pollution prevention remedies and low-cost treatment technologies. The plan of the research is well constructed, the statement of work is clear and expected progression of tasks are planned well to match objectives. The key personnel demonstrate training, experience and knowledge in the field, awareness of the dimension of the problem. The analytical methods and approaches have been adequately identified.

Broader impacts: The objective of the proposal is to improve water quality in Egypt through collaborative research between UAB in the U.S. and Alexandria University and MUST in Egypt. The project has the potential for a significant impact on developing countries, and could improve quality of life in Egypt. It will likely result in significant advancement in the water purification field in Egypt, and if successful, will greatly improve the environmental water quality in Egypt. Results will be presented in at least two workshops, one in Birmingham, Alabama, and the other in Egypt for Egyptian researchers, industrial managers and regulatory personnel. Proceedings will be prepared and submitted to the U.S.-Egypt Joint Board. The project will result in increased collaboration and interactions between UAB and Egyptian researchers, and enhance their educational outreach activities, especially undergraduate/ graduate student programs. The research may also result in significant improvement of industrial processes from the emphasis on pollution prevention and environmental management systems. The proposal addresses a real environmental issue of serious concern in a practical and achievable way.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals/objectives of this collaborative rsearch project were two-fold: (1) to foster the interaction and technical exchange of research capabilities involving U.S. and Egyptian researchers addressing water quality issues; and (2) to target research areas aimed to improve water quality in Egypt. The project had as its focus conducting planning visits. Discussion areas included: (i) prioritizing the pollutant loads/impacts of wastewaters from different industrial sectors that contribute significant quantities of pollutants to wastewaters and surface waters; (iii) identifying techniques to collect and analyze the chemical constituents and wastewater characteristics of wastewaters being discharged by various industrial firms; (iv) targeting pollution prevention assessments/audits of selected industrial firms; and (v) presenting the results (describing planned follow-on research activities in a series of workshops).

Seven tasks were performed as summarized below: 1. Comprehensive literature search; 2. Identifying targeted industrial firms to conduct pollution prevention assessments; 3. Obtaining necessary background information on the industrial processes; 4. Technology and protocol transfer; 5. Wastewater grab sample collection and chemical analyses; 6. Conducting pollution prevention assessments at targeted industrial firms; and 7. Technical dissemination of pollution prevention assessments.

Literature searches addressed: (1) oil/petroleum hydrocarbon contamination in the Nile River; (2) Nile River organic contaminants; (3) environmental contamination existing in the Nile River; (4) industrial wastewater treatment in Egypt; (5) pollution prevention audits/assessments of Egyptian industries (as pertaining to wastewater discharges); and (6) Egyptian industrial wastewater characterization and analysis. These extensive literature reviews identified more than 337 potentially relevant citations.

A result of this research included a PhD dissertation and a non-thesis Masters' degree report, listed below:

  1. Mohamed Mostafa, "Modeling of Pollutant Transport in the Nile Delta, Egypt", December, 2014, PhD Dissertation, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama; web-link: https://search-proquest-com.ezproxy3.lhl.uab.edu/pdqtlocal1006614/docview/1678609594/5108CC71B4065PQ/2?aacountid=8240.
  2. Shatha Salah, "Evaluation of Current Air Quality Issues in Egypt", April, 2016, MS non-thesis report, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama.

Additionally, eight peer-reviewed publication were generated:

  1. Mostafa, M., and R.W. Peters. 2016. "Applying the Three R's: Reduce, Reuse and Recycle in the Chemical Industry", Journal of the Air & Waste Management Association, DOI 10.1080/10962247.2016.1234421; web-link: https://tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/10962247.2016.1234421.
  2. Mostafa, M., and R.W. Peters, 2016. A Comprehensive Assessment of Water Quality at the Rosetta Branch of the Nile River, Egypt", Journal of Civil Engineering and Architecture, 10: 513-529; web-link: http://www.davidpublisher.com/Public/uploads/Contribute/575131a11a54.pdf.
  3. Mostafa, M., and R.W. Peters, 2015. "Reuse Paint Wastewater in the Manufacture of Cement Bricks and Tiles", Journal of Material Cycles and Waste Management, DOI 10.1007/s10163-016-0485-0; web-link: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mohamed_Mostafa20/publication/298217478_Reuse-paint_wastewater_in_the-manufacture_of_cement_bricks_and-tiles/links/59ec97e70f7e9bfdeb71a283/Reuse-paint-wastewater-in-the-manufacture-of-cement-bricks-and-tiles.pdf.
  4. Mostafa, M., and R.W. Peters, 2015. "Imprive Effluent Water Quality at Abu-Rawash Wastewater Treatment Plant with the Application of Coagulants". Water and Environment Journal, DOI 10.1111/wej.12161; web-link: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mohamed_Mostafa20/publication/299697808_Improve_effluent_water_quality_at_Abu_Rawash_wastewater_treatment_plant_with_application_of_coagulants/links/59ea9d2ea6fdccef8b08d7e7/Improve-effluent-water-quality-at-Abu-Rawash-wastewater-treatment-plant-with-the-application-of-coagulants.pdf.
  5. Mostafa, M., and R.W. Peters, 2015. "Use River Pollutant Modeling to Simulate and Predict the Change in the Damietta Branch Water Quality before and after Construction of the Ethiopian Dam", Journal of Environmental Protection, 6 (9): 935-945; web-link: https://www.scirp.org/pdf/JEP_2015090211351576.pdf..
  6. Mostafa, M., M.S. Mahmoud, and R.W. Peters, 2015. "Use Statistical Analyses to Assess Water Quality at the Damieta Branch of the Nile River, Egypt", Journal of Environment and Biotechnlogy Research, 2 (1): 16-26; web-link: http://www.vinanie.com/doc/JEBR_Mostafa_et_al_012016.pdf.
  7. Mostafa, M., M.M. Elshafei, and R.W. Peters, 2015. "Improve Water Quality at the El-Rahawy Drain and the Rosetta Branch, Egypt", Journal of Environmental Protection, 6 (10): 1139-1148; web-link: http://citeseers.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.1009.2276&rep=rep1&type=pdf.
  8. Mostafa, M., and R.W., Peters, 2015. "Effect of Changing the Effluent Path of Omar-Bek Drain on the Damietta Branch Water Quality", Journal of Water Resource and Protection, 8 (1): 20-30; web-link: http://www.scirp.org/pdf/JWARP_2016011314134172.pdf.

Several international workshops were held in Egypt (Cairo and Alexandria) in 2015 and 2016, summarizing the results from this research project. In 2015, breakout sessions were held at the workshops in Cairo (May 10th) and Alexandria (May 14th). In 2016, breakout sessions were held at these workshops in Cairo (May 11th) and Alexandria (May 14th).

A series of white papers were developed serving as points of discussion, listed below:

  1. Pollutant Loading in Wastewater;
  2. Sustainability of Water and Air Infrastructure;
  3. Water Sustainability;
  4. Evaluation of the Current Air Quality Condition in Egypt and the Governmental Mitigation Efforts; and
  5. Overview of Air Quality in Egypt and Opportunities for Improvement: NSF International Workshop.

Additionally, the Principal Investigator provided a keynote address at the 9th Alexandria International Conferee in Structural and Geotechnical Engineering, on December 19-21, 2016. The keynote address was entitled "Use of GIS and Drone Technology to Monitor/Assess System Health Performance". At that conference, three UAB students accompanied the researcher, and presented posters at the conference:

  1. "Creating Ceramic Filters for Third World Applications", authored by Ms. April Nabors (doctoral student);
  2. "An Assessment of Solar PV Panels in Saharan Landscapes: Performance Enhancement Methods", authored by Ms. Sandra Cutts (doctoral student); and
  3. "Maintaining Quality while Designing for a Better Future", authored by Mr. Randall Scott (undergraduate student).
